css-matches-pseudo.description: The `:matches()` (formerly `:any()`) pseudo-class checks whether the element at its position in the outer selector matches any of the selectors in its selector list. It's useful syntactic sugar that allows you to avoid writing out all the combinations manually as separate selectors. The effect is similar to nesting in Sass and most other CSS preprocessors.

links.title: WebKit blog post about adding `:matches()` and other Selectors Level 4 features
Mozilla Bug 906353 - Add support for css4 selector :matches(), the standard of :-moz-any()
Microsoft Edge UserVoice feature request for :matches()
Issue 568705: Chrome does not support :matches() selector

css-matches-pseudo.notes: Most browsers support this spelled as a prefixed `:-vendor-any()` pseudo-class.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the `:-webkit-any()` pseudo-class, which is deprecated due to handling specificity incorrectly.
notes_by_num.2: Also supports the `:-webkit-any()` pseudo-class, which is deprecated due to handling specificity incorrectly.
notes_by_num.3: Only supports the `:-moz-any()` pseudo-class.

rel-noopener.title: rel=noopener
rel-noopener.description: Ensure new browsing contexts are opened without a useful `window.opener`

css-text-justify.title: CSS text-justify
css-text-justify.description: CSS property to define how text should be justified when `text-align: justify` is set.

notes_by_num.1: Supports `inter-word`, but not `inter-character` or  `none`. Also supports the following unofficial values: `distribute` , `distribute-all-lines`, `distribute-center-last`, `inter-cluster`, `inter-ideograph`, `newspaper`. See [MSDN](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms531172%28v=vs.85%29.aspx) for details.
notes_by_num.2: `inter-word` and `distribute` values supported behind the "Experimental platform features" flag but `distribute` support [is buggy](https://crbug.com/467406)
notes_by_num.3: Behind the "layout.css.text-justify.enabled" flag
notes_by_num.4: Supports `auto`, `none`, `inter-word`, `inter-character`, and `distribute` with the exact same meaning and behavior as `inter-character` for legacy reasons.

css-scrollbar.title: CSS scrollbar styling
css-scrollbar.notes: Currently scrollbar styling doesn't appear to be on any standards track.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports styling [scrollbar colors](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms531155%28v=vs.85%29.aspx), no other properties to define the scrollbar's appearance.
notes_by_num.2: Supports scrollbar styling via CSS [pseudo-properties](https://webkit.org/blog/363/styling-scrollbars/).

link-rel-preload.title: Resource Hints: preload
link-rel-preload.description: Using `<link rel="preload">`, browsers can be informed to prefetch resources without having to execute them, allowing fine-grained control over when and how resources are loaded.

links.title: Preload: What Is It Good For?
MDN Web Docs - Preloading content with rel="preload"

notes_by_num.1: Only cachable resources can be preloaded. This includes the following `as` values: script, style, image, video, audio, track, fetch, and font (note font/collection is not supported).
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu
notes_by_num.3: Disabled by default behind the `network.preload` flag.

css-case-insensitive.title: Case-insensitive CSS attribute selectors
css-case-insensitive.description: Including an `i` before the `]` in a CSS attribute selector causes the attribute value to be matched in an ASCII-case-insensitive manner. For example, `[b="xyz" i]` would match both `<a b="xyz">` and `<a b="XYZ">`.

links.title: MS Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-default-pseudo.title: :default CSS pseudo-class
css-default-pseudo.description: The `:default` pseudo-class matches checkboxes and radio buttons which are checked by default, `<option>`s with the `selected` attribute, and the default submit button (if any) of a form.

links.title: MS Edge feature request on UserVoice
WebKit bug 156230 - `:default` CSS pseudo-class should match checkboxes+radios with a `checked` attribute

css-default-pseudo.notes: Whether `<option selected>` matches `:default` (per the spec) was not tested since `<select>`s and `<option>`s are generally not styleable, which makes it hard to formulate a test for this.

notes_by_num.1: Does not match `<input type="checkbox" checked>` or `<input type="radio" checked>`
notes_by_num.2: Does not match the default submit button of a form

css-optional-pseudo.title: :optional CSS pseudo-class
css-optional-pseudo.description: The `:optional` pseudo-class matches form inputs (`<input>`, `<textarea>`, `<select>`) which are not `:required`.

notes_by_num.1: Does not match non-required `<select>`s

css-indeterminate-pseudo.title: :indeterminate CSS pseudo-class
css-indeterminate-pseudo.description: The `:indeterminate` pseudo-class matches indeterminate checkboxes, indeterminate `<progress>` bars, and radio buttons with no checked button in their radio button group.

links.title: EdgeHTML issue 7124038 - `:indeterminate` pseudo-class doesn't match radio buttons
Mozilla Bug 885359 - Radio groups without a selected radio button should have `:indeterminate` applying
WebKit Bug 156270 - `:indeterminate` pseudo-class should match radios whose group has no checked radio

notes_by_num.1: Doesn't match radio buttons whose radio button group lacks a checked radio button
notes_by_num.2: Doesn't support the `<progress>` element
notes_by_num.3: Doesn't match indeterminate `<progress>` bars

webgl2.title: WebGL 2.0
webgl2.description: Next version of WebGL. Based on OpenGL ES 3.0.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox by setting the about:config preference webgl.enable-prototype-webgl2 to true
notes_by_num.2: WebGL2 context is accessed from "experimental-webgl2" rather than "webgl2"
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled in Chrome by passing the "--enable-unsafe-es3-apis" flag when starting the browser through the command line
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu
notes_by_num.5: Enabled by default for Nightly and Dev Edition

css-initial-letter.title: CSS Initial Letter
css-initial-letter.description: Method of creating an enlarged cap, including a drop or raised cap, in a robust way.

links.title: Blog post on Envato Tuts+, "Better CSS Drop Caps With initial-letter"

notes_by_num.1: Safari implementation is incomplete. Does not allow applying web fonts to the initial letter.

document-currentscript.title: document.currentScript
document-currentscript.description: `document.currentScript` returns the `<script>` element whose script is currently being processed.

css-descendant-gtgt.title: Explicit descendant combinator >>
css-descendant-gtgt.description: An explicit, non-whitespace spelling of the descendant combinator. `A >> B` is equivalent to `A B`.

links.title: Mozilla bug #1266283 - Implement CSS4 descendant combinator `>>`

same-site-cookie-attribute.title: 'SameSite' cookie attribute
same-site-cookie-attribute.description: Same-site cookies (née "First-Party-Only" (née "First-Party")) allow servers to mitigate the risk of CSRF and information leakage attacks by asserting that a particular cookie should only be sent with requests initiated from the same registrable domain.

links.title: Preventing CSRF with the same-site cookie attribute
Mozilla Bug #795346: Add SameSite support for cookies

same-site-cookie-attribute.notes: This feature is backwards compatible. Browsers not supporting this feature will simply use the cookie as a regular cookie. There is no need to deliver different cookies to clients.

css-has.title: :has() CSS relational pseudo-class
css-has.description: Only select elements containing specified content. For example, `a:has(>img)` selects all `` elements that contain an `` child.

css-not-sel-list.title: selector list argument of :not()
css-not-sel-list.description: Selectors Level 4 allows the `:not()` pseudo-class to accept a list of selectors, which the element must not match any of. Selectors Level 3 only allowed `:not()` to accept a single simple selector. Thus, `:not(a):not(.b):not([c])` can instead be written as `:not(a, .b, [c])`

credential-management.title: Credential Management API
credential-management.description: API that provides a programmatic interface to the browser's credential manager. In short, an origin can request a user's credentials to sign them in, or can ask the browser to save credentials on the user's behalf. Both of these requests are user-mediated.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Credential Management API

notes_by_num.1: In Chrome 51 ~ 56, PSL matched credentials are not supported. This means you cannot use credentials set on a.example.com in b.example.com. This is supported since Chrome 57.

css-dir-pseudo.title: :dir() CSS pseudo-class
css-dir-pseudo.description: Matches elements based on their directionality. `:dir(ltr)` matches elements which are Left-to-Right. `:dir(rtl)` matches elements which are Right-to-Left.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
WebKit bug #64861: Need support for :dir() pseudo-class

css-focus-within.title: :focus-within CSS pseudo-class
css-focus-within.description: The `:focus-within` pseudo-class matches elements that either themselves match `:focus` or that have descendants which match `:focus`.

links.title: The Future Generation of CSS Selectors: Level 4: Generalized Input Focus Pseudo-class
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
WebKit bug #140144: Add support for CSS4 `:focus-within` pseudo
Chromium issue #617371: Implement `:focus-within` pseudo-class from Selectors Level 4
Mozilla bug #1176997: Add support for pseudo class `:focus-within`

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag

dom-manip-convenience.title: DOM manipulation convenience methods
dom-manip-convenience.description: jQuery-like methods on DOM nodes to insert nodes around or within a node, or to replace one node with another. These methods accept any number of DOM nodes or HTML strings as arguments. Includes: `ChildNode.before`, `ChildNode.after`, `ChildNode.replaceWith`, `ParentNode.prepend`, and `ParentNode.append`.

links.title: MS Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "Enable Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in chrome://flags

requestidlecallback.title: requestIdleCallback
requestidlecallback.description: API allowing the execution of JavaScript to be queued to run in idle browser time, either at the end of a frame or when the user is inactive. Also covers support for `cancelIdleCallback`. The API has similarities with `requestAnimationFrame`.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `dom.requestIdleCallback.enabled` flag

scrollintoviewifneeded.title: Element.scrollIntoViewIfNeeded()
scrollintoviewifneeded.description: If the element is fully within the visible area of the viewport, it does nothing. Otherwise, the element is scrolled into view. A proprietary variant of the standard `Element.scrollIntoView()` method.

links.title: W3C CSSOM View bug #17152: Support centering an element when scrolling into view.

css3-attr.title: CSS3 attr() function
css3-attr.description: CSS Values and Units Level 3 adds the ability to use `attr()` on any CSS property, not just `content`, and to use it for non-string values (e.g. numbers, colors).

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
Mozilla Bug #435426: implement css3-values extensions to `attr()`
Chromium issue #246571: Implement CSS3 attribute / attr references
WebKit Bug #26609: Support CSS3 attr() function
Shared Dictionary Compression for HTTP at LinkedIn.

css-containment.title: CSS Containment
css-containment.description: The CSS `contain` property lets developers limit the scope of the browser's styles, layout and paint work for faster and more efficient rendering.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag

tls1-2.title: TLS 1.2
tls1-2.description: The latest version of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol. Allows for data/message confidentiality, and message authentication codes for message integrity and as a by-product message authentication.

tls1-1.title: TLS 1.1
tls1-1.description: Version 1.1 of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol.

input-inputmode.title: inputmode attribute
input-inputmode.description: The `inputmode` attribute specifies what kind of input mechanism would be most helpful for users entering content into the form control.
input-inputmode.notes:
Firefox OS is reported to have partial support for this property as `x-inputmode`.

Blink-based browsers appear to recognize the `inputMode` property on `input` & `textarea` fields though it is unclear what effect it currently has as the feature is still in development.

notes_by_num.1: Support can be enabled via the `dom.forms.inputmode` flag

ch-unit.title: ch (character) unit
ch-unit.description: Unit representing the width of the character "0" in the current font, of particular use in combination with monospace fonts.

links.title: Blog post on using ch units
Various uses for the ch unit

notes_by_num.1: IE supports the `ch` unit, but unlike other browsers its width is that specifically of the "0" glyph, not its surrounding space. As a result, 3ch for example is shorter than the width of the string "000" in IE.

img-naturalwidth-naturalheight.title: naturalWidth & naturalHeight image properties
img-naturalwidth-naturalheight.description: Properties defining the intrinsic width and height of the image, rather than the displayed width & height.

links.title: Blog post on support in IE
gist on getting natural width & height in older IE

filereadersync.title: FileReaderSync
filereadersync.description: Allows files to be read synchronously in Web Workers

mediarecorder.title: MediaRecorder API
mediarecorder.description: The MediaRecorder API (MediaStream Recording) aims to provide a really simple mechanism by which developers can record media streams from the user's input devices and instantly use them in web apps, rather than having to perform manual encoding operations on raw PCM data, etc.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the experimental Web Platform features flag. Does not support audio recording, only video.

readonly-attr.title: readonly attribute of input and textarea elements
readonly-attr.description: Makes the form control non-editable. Unlike the `disabled` attribute, `readonly` form controls are still included in form submissions and the user can still select (but not edit) their value text.

links.title: WHATWG HTML specification for the readonly attribute of the `<textarea>` element

notes_by_num.1: Readonly inputs of type `datetime-local`, `date`, `month`, and `week` can still be edited by pressing the Up or Down arrow keys on the keyboard while the input is focused.
notes_by_num.2: Text cannot be selected directly, but is possible by first selecting any text around the field.

x-frame-options.title: X-Frame-Options HTTP header
x-frame-options.description: An HTTP header which indicates whether the browser should allow the webpage to be displayed in a frame within another webpage. Used as a defense against clickjacking attacks.

links.title: IE8 Security Part VII: ClickJacking Defenses - IEBlog

x-frame-options.notes:
Partial support refers to not supporting the `ALLOW-FROM` option.
The `X-Frame-Options` header has been obsoleted by [the `frame-ancestors` directive](https://www.w3.org/TR/CSP2/#directive-frame-ancestors) from Content Security Policy Level 2.

indeterminate-checkbox.title: indeterminate checkbox
indeterminate-checkbox.description: Indeterminate checkboxes are displayed in a state which is distinct both from being checked or being unchecked. They are commonly used in hierarchical checkboxes to indicate that only some of the checkbox's descendants are checked.

links.title: WebKit Bug 160484 - iOS doesn't support indeterminate checkboxes

indeterminate-checkbox.notes: Indeterminacy does not affect a checkbox's checkedness state. It merely affects how the checkbox is displayed.

tabindex-attr.title: tabindex global attribute
tabindex-attr.description: Specifies the focusability of the element and in what order (if any) it should become focused (relative to other elements) when "tabbing" through the document.
tabindex-attr.notes:
Mac OS X "Full Keyboard Access" refers to setting Keyboard→Shortcuts→Full Keyboard Access to "All controls" in the System Preferences.

"Unknown" support for mobile browsers is due to lacking a method of tabbing through fields.

notes_by_num.1: On Mac OS X, unless Full Keyboard Access is enabled, `<a>` elements are not keyboard-focusable, even if they have `tabindex="0"`.
notes_by_num.2: `<a>` elements are never keyboard-focusable, even if they have `tabindex="0"`. Unless Full Keyboard Access is enabled, then `<button>`s, radio buttons, and checkboxes are also not keyboard-focusable, even if they have `tabindex="0"`.
notes_by_num.3: Has "previous" and "next" virtual keyboard buttons that follow tabindex order.

textencoder.title: TextEncoder & TextDecoder
textencoder.description: `TextEncoder` encodes a JavaScript string into bytes using the UTF-8 encoding and returns the resulting `Uint8Array` of those bytes. `TextDecoder` does the reverse.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
WebKit Bug 160653 - Support TextEncoder & TextDecoder APIs

notes_by_num.1: Not available in Web Workers in Firefox 19.

element-from-point.title: document.elementFromPoint()
element-from-point.description: Given coordinates for a point relative to the viewport, returns the element that a click event would be dispatched at if the user were to click the point (in other words, the element that hit-testing would find).

insert-adjacent.title: Element.insertAdjacentElement() & Element.insertAdjacentText()
insert-adjacent.description: Methods for inserting an element or text before or after a given element, or appending or prepending an element or text to a given element's list of children.

once-event-listener.title: "once" event listener option
once-event-listener.description: Causes an event listener to be automatically removed after it gets invoked, so that it only gets invoked once. Similar to jQuery's `$.one()` feature.

links.title: Chromium Issue 615384: Support "once" event listener option
MS Edge feature request on UserVoice

passive-event-listener.title: Passive event listeners
passive-event-listener.description: Event listeners created with the `passive: true` option cannot cancel (`preventDefault()`) the events they receive. Primarily intended to be used with touch events and `wheel` events. Since they cannot prevent scrolls, passive event listeners allow the browser to perform optimizations that result in smoother scrolling.

links.title: Improving scroll performance with passive event listeners - Google Developers Updates

selection-api.title: Selection API
selection-api.description: API for accessing selected content of a document, including the `window.getSelection()` method, as well as the `selectstart` & `selectionchange` events on `document`.
selection-api.notes: See also support for the related [DOM range](http://caniuse.com/#feat=dom-range)

notes_by_num.1: Supports `window.getSelection()` but no selection events
notes_by_num.2: Supports selection events, but not `window.getSelection()`
notes_by_num.3: Does not support the `selectstart` event
notes_by_num.4: `window.getSelection()` may fail on tapping buttons, as the selection is lost right before the listener code runs.
notes_by_num.5: Selection events are supported behind the `dom.select_events.enabled` flag

payment-request.title: Payment Request API
payment-request.description: Payment Request is a new API for the open web that makes checkout flows easier, faster and consistent on shopping sites.

links.title: Bringing easy and fast checkout with Payment Request API
MDN Web Docs - Payment Request API

payment-request.notes: Apple provides an equivalent proprietary API called [Apple Pay JS](https://developer.apple.com/reference/applepayjs/). Google provides a [PaymentRequest wrapper for Apple Pay JS](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/appr-wrapper).

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Payments API" flag
notes_by_num.3: Apple's proprietary implementation (see above)
notes_by_num.4: Can be enabled via the "[Web Payments API](chrome://flags/#web-payments)" flag
notes_by_num.5: Unlike Desktop Chrome, support has been in Chrome for Android since version 53.
notes_by_num.6: Can be enabled via the `dom.payments.request.enabled` flag in "about:config" flag since 55.

shadowdomv1.title: Shadow DOM v1
shadowdomv1.description: Method of establishing and maintaining functional boundaries between DOM trees and how these trees interact with each other within a document, thus enabling better functional encapsulation within the DOM & CSS.

links.title: Google Developers - Shadow DOM v1: self-contained web components

shadowdomv1.notes: Shadow DOM v0 was implemented in Chrome/Opera but other browser vendors are implementing v1.

notes_by_num.1: Certain CSS selectors do not work (`:host > .local-child`) and styling slotted content (`::slotted`) is buggy.

urlsearchparams.title: URLSearchParams
urlsearchparams.description: The URLSearchParams interface defines utility methods to work with the query string of a URL.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only supporting `entries()`, `keys()`, `values()`, and `for...of`.

css-font-rendering-controls.title: CSS font-rendering controls
css-font-rendering-controls.description: `@font-face` descriptor (currently defined as `font-display`) that allows control over how a downloadable font renders before it is fully loaded.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled in Firefox through the `layout.css.font-display.enabled` flag at about:config

wasm.title: WebAssembly
wasm.description: WebAssembly or "wasm" is a new portable, size- and load-time-efficient format suitable for compilation to the web.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `javascript.options.wasm` in `about:config`
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled via the `#enable-webassembly` flag
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled via the Experimental JavaScript Features flag
notes_by_num.4: Disabled for Firefox 52 ESR

css-paged-media.title: CSS Paged Media (@page)
css-paged-media.description: CSS at-rule (`@page`) to define page-specific rules when printing web pages, such as margin per page and page dimensions.
css-paged-media.notes: Currently no browsers appear to support the `marks` & `bleed` properties from the latest version of the specification.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the `size` property
notes_by_num.2: Does not appear to have a way to print web pages

childnode-remove.title: ChildNode.remove()
childnode-remove.description: DOM node method to remove the node itself from the document.

css-first-line.title: CSS first-line pseudo-element
css-first-line.description: Allows styling specifically for the first line of text using the `::first-line` pseudo-element. Note that only a limited set of properties can be applied.

notes_by_num.1: IE8 only supports the single-colon CSS 2.1 syntax (i.e. `:first-line`). It does not support the double-colon CSS3 syntax (i.e. `::first-line`).

mutation-events.title: Mutation events
mutation-events.description: Deprecated mechanism for listening to changes made to the DOM, replaced by Mutation Observers.
mutation-events.notes: See also support for [Mutation Observer](http://caniuse.com/#feat=mutationobserver), which replaces mutation events and does not have the same performance drawbacks.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `DOMAttrModified`
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `DOMNodeInsertedIntoDocument` & `DOMNodeRemovedFromDocument`

web-app-manifest.title: Web App Manifest
web-app-manifest.description: The web app manifest provides information about an application (such as name, author, icon, and description) in a JSON file, which browsers can use to give richer offline experiences.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Web App Manifest
Tool to generate a manifest from any given URL

comparedocumentposition.title: Node.compareDocumentPosition()
comparedocumentposition.description: Compares the relative position of two nodes to each other in the DOM tree.

notes_by_num.1: The spec requires that comparisons of nodes in different documents, and comparisons where at least one node is not in any document, must arbitrarily (but consistently) set either the `DOCUMENT_POSITION_PRECEDING` or `DOCUMENT_POSITION_FOLLOWING` bit in the result. These browser versions don't set either bit in some such cases.
notes_by_num.2: Sets neither the `DOCUMENT_POSITION_DISCONNECTED` bit nor the `DOCUMENT_POSITION_IMPLEMENTATION_SPECIFIC` bit in some cases when comparing nodes in different documents or when comparing a node which is not in any document.

http-live-streaming.title: HTTP Live Streaming (HLS)
http-live-streaming.notes: HLS is being replaced by Dynamic Adaptive Streaming over HTTP (aka MPEG-DASH)

links.title: Blog post: Native ECMAScript modules - the first overview
Counterpart ECMAScript specification for import/export syntax

notes_by_num.1: Support can be enabled via `about:flags`
notes_by_num.2: Support can be enabled via `about:config`
notes_by_num.3: Support can be enabled via the `experimental-web-platform-features` flag

es6-class.title: ES6 classes
es6-class.description: ES6 classes are syntactical sugar to provide a much simpler and clearer syntax to create objects and deal with inheritance.

links.title: Sitepoint deep dive on ES6 classes
List of resources critical of ES6 classes

notes_by_num.1: Requires strict mode. Non-strict mode support is behind the flag 'Enable Experimental JavaScript', disabled by default.

ping.title: Ping attribute
ping.description: When used on an anchor, this attribute signifies that the browser should a ping request the resource the attribute points to.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Element ping attribute

ping.notes: While still in the WHATWG specification, this feature was removed from the W3C HTML5 specification in 2010.

notes_by_num.1: Disabled by default for [privacy reasons](http://kb.mozillazine.org/Browser.send_pings). Can be enabled via the `browser.send_pings` flag.

form-submit-attributes.title: Attributes for form submission
form-submit-attributes.description: Attributes for form submission that may be specified on submit buttons. The attributes are: `formaction`, `formenctype`, `formmethod`, `formnovalidate`, and `formtarget`

async-functions.title: Async functions
async-functions.description: Async function make it possible to treat functions returning Promise objects as if they were synchronous.

notes_by_num.1: Since build 14342 - disabled by default; can be enabled through about:flags
notes_by_num.2: Async functions are present in Firefox Nightly since 31th October 2016.

html-media-capture.title: HTML Media Capture
html-media-capture.description: Facilitates user access to a device's media capture mechanism, such as a camera, or microphone, from within a file upload control.

links.title: Correct Syntax for HTML Media Capture
Programming the Mobile Web: File upload compatibility table

notes_by_num.1: iOS6-10 do not support the capture attribute used to force capture straight from the device's camera or microphone. Also note that default video dimensions are 480x320 (4:3).
notes_by_num.2: Android 2.2-2.3 do not support the capture attribute
notes_by_num.3: Supports a "capture" button for any `<input type="file"> field, regardless of the whether the capture attribute is used.

html-media-capture.keywords: htmlmediacapture, html media capture, media capture, mediacapture

css-text-indent.title: CSS text-indent
css-text-indent.description: The `text-indent` property applies indentation to lines of inline content in a block.

links.title: Article on using text-indent for image replacement

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to supporting a `<length>` value, but not the `each-line` or `hanging` keywords.
notes_by_num.2: Support for `each-line` & `hanging` is available behind the Experimental Web Platform features flag

intersectionobserver.title: IntersectionObserver
intersectionobserver.description: API that can be used to understand the visibility and position of DOM elements relative to a containing element or to the top-level viewport. The position is delivered asynchronously and is useful for understanding the visibility of elements and implementing pre-loading and deferred loading of DOM content.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Firefox by setting the `about:config` preference `dom.IntersectionObserver.enabled` to true
notes_by_num.2: "Preliminary" support as feature is still in development

css-marker-pseudo.title: CSS ::marker pseudo-element
css-marker-pseudo.description: The `::marker` pseudo-element allows list item markers to be styled or have their content value customized.

notes_by_num.1: Safari supports [the definition in the CSS Pseudo-Elements Module Level 4](https://www.w3.org/TR/css-pseudo-4/#marker-pseudo) instead of one in the List module due to the flux definition in it.

dommatrix.title: DOMMatrix
dommatrix.description: The `DOMMatrix` interface represents 4x4 matrices, suitable for 2D and 3D operations. Supersedes the `WebKitCSSMatrix` and `SVGMatrix` interfaces.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the `WebKitCSSMatrix` version of the interface, not `DOMMatrix`
notes_by_num.2: `WebKitCSSMatrix#skewX`, `WebKitCSSMatrix#skewY` are not supported
notes_by_num.3: Only supports the `DOMMatrix` version of the interface, not `WebKitCSSMatrix` (support required by spec for legacy reasons)

url.title: URL API
url.description: API to retrieve the various parts that make up a given URL from a given URL string.

notes_by_num.1: Allows objects to be created via `URL` constructor, but instances do not have the expected url properties.

flow-root.title: display: flow-root
flow-root.description: The element generates a block container box, and lays out its contents using flow layout. It always establishes a new block formatting context for its contents. The result is the same as the "clearfix" hack.

links.title: Blog post: "The end of the clearfix hack?"

css-rrggbbaa.title: #rrggbbaa hex color notation
css-rrggbbaa.description: The CSS Color Module Level 4 defines new 4 & 8 character hex notation for color to include the opacity level.
css-rrggbbaa.notes: Support in Android WebView is currently disabled due to [this issue](http://crbug.com/618472)

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental web platform features" flag.

beforeafterprint.title: Printing Events
beforeafterprint.description: Window fires `beforeprint` and `afterprint` events so the printed document can be annotated.

links.title: MDN Web Docs - Detecting print requests

beforeafterprint.notes: Due to its wider support, consider using `window.matchMedia('print')` where possible.

tls1-3.title: TLS 1.3
tls1-3.description: An upcoming version of the Transport Layer Security (TLS) protocol. Removes weaker elliptic curves and hash functions.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled by setting "TLS 1.3" to "Enabled (Draft)" at `chrome://flags/tls13-variant`.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled by setting "Maximum TLS version enabled" to "TLS 1.3"at `chrome://flags/`. Support is reported to have be currently enabled as of version 56 for 1/10th of all users.

webvr.title: WebVR API
webvr.description: API for accessing virtual reality (VR) devices, including sensors and head-mounted displays.
webvr.notes: Not every computer or smartphone could run WebVR appication. For smartphones, you need a gyroscope and for computers must be VR-ready also the needed sotfware (Oculus client or (Steam VR and VivePort)) and drivers must been installed on the computer. In this situations, you've the best experiance to use WebVR applications.

notes_by_num.1: Available and enabled by default only in Firefox Windows. Enabled in Nightly for iOS.
notes_by_num.2: Enabled behind the WebVR & "Gamepad Extensions" flags under `chrome://flags`. Currently builds use an older version of the (still changing) specification and supports only the Oculus Rift and the HTC vive on Windows VR-ready computers.
notes_by_num.3: [In development](https://blogs.windows.com/msedgedev/2016/09/09/webvr-in-development-edge/#3lMW05DTZXbXcK46.97) in the latest Edge builds and supports only [Windows Mixed Reality](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/mixed-reality).
notes_by_num.4: Supports only Samsung Galaxy devices with the Samgung Gear VR
notes_by_num.5: Supports only Google Daydream on [daydream-ready devices](https://vr.google.com/daydream/smartphonevr/phones/) and Google Cardboards

css-apply-rule.title: CSS @apply rule
css-apply-rule.description: Allows a set of CSS properties to be applied using a named variable

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental web platform features" flag under about:flags

css-hanging-punctuation.title: CSS hanging-punctuation
css-hanging-punctuation.description: Allows some punctuation characters from start (or the end) of text elements to be placed "outside" of the box in order to preserve the reading flow.

background-repeat-round-space.title: CSS background-repeat round and space
background-repeat-round-space.description: Allows CSS background images to be repeated without clipping.

notes_by_num.1: IE9 does not appear to render "background-repeat: round" correctly.

document-evaluate-xpath.title: document.evaluate & XPath
document-evaluate-xpath.description: Allow nodes in an XML/HTML document to be traversed using XPath expressions.

css-namespaces.title: CSS namespaces
css-namespaces.description: Using the `@namespace` at-rule, elements of other namespaces (e.g. SVG) can be targeted using the pipe (`|`) selector.

css-overflow-anchor.title: CSS overflow-anchor (Scroll Anchoring)
css-overflow-anchor.description:
Changes in DOM elements above the visible region of a scrolling box can result in the page moving while the user is in the middle of consuming the content.
By default, the value of  `overflow-anchor` is `auto`, it can mitigate this jarring user experience by keeping track of the position of an anchor node and adjusting the scroll offset accordingly
css-overflow-anchor.notes: Mozilla has discussed a similar feature in [Bug 43114](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=43114).

hardwareconcurrency.title: navigator.hardwareConcurrency
hardwareconcurrency.description: Returns the number of logical cores of the user's CPU. The value may be reduced to prevent device fingerprinting or because it exceeds the allowed number of simultaneous web workers.

notes_by_num.1: Webkit browsers clamp the maximum value returned to 2 on iOS devices and 8 on all others. Disabled in Safari behind the ENABLE_NAVIGATOR_HWCONCURRENCY build option.

css-rebeccapurple.title: Rebeccapurple color
css-rebeccapurple.description: The new color added in CSS Color Module Level 4

notes_by_num.1: Only works in IE11 for Windows 10, not older versions of Windows

rel-noreferrer.title: Link type "noreferrer"
rel-noreferrer.description: Links with `rel="noreferrer"` set do not send the request's "referrer" header. This prevents the destination site from seeing what URL the user came from.

notes_by_num.1: Only supported in IE11 in later versions of Windows 10 (creators update).

css-display-contents.title: CSS display: contents
css-display-contents.description: `display: contents` causes an element's children to appear as if they were direct children of the element's parent, ignoring the element itself. This can be useful when a wrapper element should be ignored when using CSS grid or similar layout techniques.

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags

eme.title: Encrypted Media Extensions
eme.description: The EncryptedMediaExtenstions API provides interfaces for controlling the playback of content which is subject to a DRM scheme.

links.title: Encrypted Media Extensions API on MDN

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the older event-based specification

web-share.title: Web Share API
web-share.description: A way to allow websites to invoke the native sharing capabilities of the host platform

links.title: Web Share API brings the native sharing capabilities to the browser
Mozilla bug #1312422: Consider experimental support for Web Share API

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to feature only being available for sites opting into the [origin trial](https://github.com/GoogleChrome/OriginTrials/blob/gh-pages/developer-guide.md)
notes_by_num.2: Implemented old [Web Intents](https://dvcs.w3.org/hg/web-intents/raw-file/tip/spec/Overview-respec.html)
notes_by_num.3: Android [intent://](https://developer.chrome.com/multidevice/android/intents) URLs can be used instead.

css-text-orientation.title: CSS text-orientation
css-text-orientation.description: The CSS `text-orientation` property specifies the orientation of text within a line. Current values only have an effect in vertical typographic modes (defined with the `writing-mode` property)

indexeddb2.title: IndexedDB 2.0
indexeddb2.description: Improvements to Indexed DB, including getAll(), renaming stores and indexes, and binary keys.

links.title: Mozilla Hacks: What's new in IndexedDB 2.0?

notes_by_num.1: Missing: IDBKeyRange includes(), renaming stores/indexes, binary keys, IDBObjectStore getKey(), IDBCursor continuePrimaryKey()
notes_by_num.2: Missing: Renaming stores/indexes, binary keys, IDBObjectStore getKey(), IDBCursor continuePrimaryKey()

hevc.title: HEVC/H.265 video format
hevc.description: The High Efficiency Video Coding (HEVC) compression standard is a video compression format intended to succeed H.264

notes_by_num.1: Supported only for devices with [hardware support](https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/insider/forum/insider_apps-insider_wmp/windows-10-hevc-playback-yes-or-no/3c1ab780-a6b2-4b77-ac0f-9faeefd4680d)
notes_by_num.2: Reported to work in certain Android devices with hardware support
notes_by_num.3: Supported only on macOS High Sierra

resizeobserver.title: Resize Observer
resizeobserver.description: Method for observing and reacting to changes to sizes of DOM elements.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag

heif.title: HEIF/ISO Base Media File Format
heif.description: HEIF (High Efficiency Image File Format) is a standard developed by the Moving Picture Experts Group (MPEG) for storage and sharing of images and image sequences.

notes_by_num.1: While supported natively in macOS High Sierra and iOS 11, the file format does not appear to be supported in Safari.

localecompare.title: localeCompare()
localecompare.description: The `localeCompare()` method returns a number indicating whether a reference string comes before or after or is the same as the given string in sort order.

notes_by_num.1: Only supports basic support without locale & options parameters.

input-file-directory.title: Directory selection from file input
input-file-directory.description: The `webkitdirectory` attribute on the `<input type="file">` element allows entire directory with file contents (and any subdirectories) to be selected.
input-file-directory.notes: Lack of support in mobile browsers may be due to the OS file picker not having support for selecting a directory.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Features" developer menu

constraint-validation.title: Constraint Validation API
constraint-validation.description: API for better control over form field validation. Includes support for `checkValidity()`, `setCustomValidity()`, `reportValidity()` and validation states.

links.title: MS Edge UserVoice request for reportValidity

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `reportValidity`
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `validity.tooShort`. See also [support for `minlength`.](http://caniuse.com/#feat=input-minlength)
notes_by_num.3: Does not support `validity.badInput`

css-conic-gradients.title: CSS Conical Gradients
css-conic-gradients.description: Method of defining a conical or repeating conical color gradient as a CSS image.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
Mozilla bug #1175958: Implement conic gradients from CSS Image Values Level 4

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag

css-caret-color.title: CSS caret-color
css-caret-color.description: The `caret-color` property allows the color to be set of the caret (blinking text insertion pointer) in an editable text area.

offscreencanvas.title: OffscreenCanvas
offscreencanvas.description: OffscreenCanvas allows canvas drawing to occur with no connection to the DOM and can be used inside workers.

links.title: WebGL off the main thread - Mozilla Hacks article

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `gfx.offscreencanvas.enabled` flag. Currently only supports WebGL contexts, not 2D.
notes_by_num.2: Can be enabled via the `Experimental canvas features` flag

es6-generators.title: ES6 Generators
es6-generators.description: ES6 Generators are special functions that can be used to control the iteration behavior of a loop. Generators are defined using a `function*` declaration.

mpeg-dash.title: Dynamic Adaptive Streaming over HTTP (MPEG-DASH)
mpeg-dash.description: HTTP-based media streaming communications protocol, an alternative to HTTP Live Streaming (HLS).
mpeg-dash.notes: DASH can be used with a JavaScript library in browsers that doesn't support it natively as long as they support [Media Source Extensions](/#feat=mediasource).

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled via the `media.dash.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Only WebM video is supported.

unhandledrejection.title: unhandledrejection/rejectionhandled events
unhandledrejection.description: The `unhandledrejection` event is fired when a Promise is rejected but there is no rejection handler to deal with the rejection. The `rejectionhandled` event is fired when a Promise is rejected, and after the rejection is handled by the promise's rejection handling code.

path2d.title: Path2D
path2d.description: Allows path objects to be declared on 2D canvas surfaces

notes_by_num.1: Does not support the `addPath()` method

webusb.title: WebUSB
webusb.description: Allows communication with devices via USB (Universal Serial Bus).

input-selection.title: Selection controls for input & textarea
input-selection.description: Controls for setting and getting text selection via `setSelectionRange()` and the `selectionStart` & `selectionEnd` properties.

media-fragments.title: Media Fragments
media-fragments.description: Allows only part of a resource to be shown, based on the fragment identifier in the URL. Currently support is primarily limited to video track ranges.

notes_by_num.1: Only appears to support the `#t=n,n` control for selecting a range of video, and possibly `track=(name)` & `id=(name)` (not yet tested)

css-focus-ring.title: :focus-ring CSS pseudo-class
css-focus-ring.description: The `:focus-ring` pseudo-class applies while an element matches the `:focus` pseudo-class, and the UA determines via heuristics that the focus should be specially indicated on the element (typically via a “focus ring”).

links.title: WebKit bug #140144: Add support for `-webkit-focusring` CSS pseudo class
Chromium issue #271023: Outline should not appear on elements focused by mouse

notes_by_num.1: As `-moz-focusring`

streams.title: Streams
streams.description: Method of creating, composing, and consuming streams of data, that map efficiently to low-level I/O primitives, and allow easy composition with built-in backpressure and queuing.

notes_by_num.1: IE implements a different API than the one from WHATWG.
notes_by_num.2: Only basic read support.
notes_by_num.3: Disabled by default behind the `javascript.options.streams` and `dom.streams.enabled` flags.
notes_by_num.4: No support for BYOB ("bring your own buffer") stream readers.
notes_by_num.6: No support for the `pipeTo` or `pipeThrough` methods

variable-fonts.title: Variable fonts
variable-fonts.description: OpenType font settings that allows a single font file to behave like multiple fonts: it can contain all the allowed variations in width, weight, slant, optical size, or any other exposed axes of variation as defined by the font designer. Variations can be applied via the `font-variation-settings` property.

links.title: Axis-Praxs - Tool & info on variable fonts

variable-fonts.notes: Variable fonts are still developing, but can be used with @supports in CSS to more safely put them in to use.

notes_by_num.1: Works with Experimental Web Platform features enabled
notes_by_num.2:
Requires MacOS 10.12+ and the following about:config flags to be enabled:
`layout.css.font-variations.enabled`,
`gfx.downloadable_fonts.keep_variation_tables`
notes_by_num.3: Requires MacOS 10.13+

variable-fonts.keywords: variable fonts, variation fonts, font variations
